bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, December 1, 1944

div1.p: Hench describes his visits with the Keans and Ramos. An exhibit of the Cornwall painting is planned in Cuba. He describes a mural by a Cuban artist entitled, “The Martyrs of the Conquest of Yellow Fever.”

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, December 1, 1944
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
1 December, 1944
Brigadier General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I have been meaning to write to you for a long time, but have
been very busy. Last month we gave an exhibit on Arthritis from this hos-
pital, at the meeting of the Association of Military Surgeons in New York and,
thereafter, I spent two days in Washington. I had such a nice visit with
General and Mrs. Kean. In New York, I met Doctor Ramos, former Secretary of
War in the Cuban Government, now Director of the Finlay Institute. He is try-
ing to arrange an exhibit of all the Cornwell paintings in Cuba sometime this
next Spring. We visited Cornwell, and saw the newest painting in the series,
an excellent one of Oliver Wendell Holmes. Ramos hopes to commission Cornwell
to paint something approaching the “Cuban version” of the Yellow Fever painting
for the Finlay Institute.

Had I told you that, this Summer, a young Cuban artist, Raquel
Romero, flew here to see me and to show me her preliminary sketch of “The
Martyrs of the Conquest of Yellow Fever”, which she was commissioned to do as
a mural in a lecture room or auditorium in a large new National hospital being
built on the grounds of the military city (Old Camp Columbia)? I enclose a
little picture of Miss Romero and her sketch. It is rather simple, but I think
the conception is interesting. It is supposed to represent two episodes that
occurred in Las Animas Hospital. On the left is a yellow fever patient, with
Doctor Lazear infecting a mosquito. The nurse standing by is Miss Mass. On
the right is Doctor Guiteras, infecting Miss Mass, and behind her stand the
other two Cubans who, with Miss Mass, died of experimental fever in the late
series of Doctor Guiteras. The large figure in the foreground is allegorical
and has aroused a little controversy. Miss Romero wanted to tie the two ep-
isodes together, and also wanted to indicate that the efforts of these people
and their martyrdom were receiving the accolade of humanity. The large figure,
therefore, is supposed to represent Humanity. Her classical robe is colored
yellow, the color allocated for the medical degree in Cuba. I feared that when
this mural appeared, in its large size, this figure in the foreground would be
mammoth and overpowering. I suggested that she tone it down; also, I suggested
a little relief from the austerity of the rest of the panel, and she was planning
to put a little decorative motif in the upper right and left corners, and poss-
ibly in the center, perhaps composed of a little draping with the Cuban and
American flags, and perhaps the Caduceus. She may change her mind on the latter,
however. Doctor Ramos tells me that the mural is practically finished, and
it will be interesting to see how it turns out.

I am enclosing an interesting article about Cornwell. I regret
Sheet Two
To: Brig. Gen. A. E. Truby
PSH/cb
1 December 1944
that I must ask you to return it to me. If you should want one, it might
be possible to write to the magazine for a copy, and you will find the
address at the bottom of the next to the last page.

I have had so little time to spend on the Yellow Fever hobby.
I notice your request to give you a photostat copy of the remarks that
Doctor Reed made about you in one of his letters. In your letter of October
3rd, you date this letter as November 20, 1899. I thought I had sent you a
copy, but obviously I have not. I have here in my room all of Walter Reed's
letters to his family and can not find one dated November 20, 1899. Perhaps
that letter is one that General Kean may have given me, one of the letters of
Reed's which I have in a bank vault in Rochester. Do you remember when I
mentioned it? I tried, one evening, to find mention of it in my voluminous
correspondence with you, but could not do so. If you could give me the date
of my letters about it, it will help me to find the Reed letter. In any
event, I will look through the other Reed letters I have at home, when I go
home in about three weeks, for Christmas.

I am glad you agree that the one officer in the group by the
tree at Camp Lazear is Doctor Cooke. I was sure that it was he, and I be-
lieve you were right that figure No. 4 is Kissinger. I can't quite see
figure No. 7 as Walter Reed, and General Kean could not, either. General
Kean was disturbed to see the children in the photograph, and wondered how
they got there. As you know, he did not believe the picture was taken at
Camp Lazear, but I can not mistake the tree, and in the center background
is the tent. Can you explain why the children are there? I am going to send
a copy of the photograph to Doctor Cooke for his identification, and, also,
probably to Mr. Kissinger.

Would you like to have any more copies of my article in Hygeia,
with the colored reproduction of the Yellow Fever painting? I have quite a
lot of them at home and would be delighted to send you as many as you wish,
25, 50, even 100, as many of them as you want.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely yours, PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service Enc - Photographs (2)
Magazine, “American Artist”
dtd April 1942.
